sect2.title: Outgoing Server
sect2.para: The Outgoing Server tab, as seen in , lets administrators control how ⪚ sends emails.

The ⪚ sends emails for several reasons. Various Software Appliances (for example, Virus Scanning) will send end-users emails informing them of malicious payloads such as viruses. The Quarantine feature sends users a daily digest of the spams they received, and the EdgeGuard Reports Appliance sends daily summary reports to administrators about their ⪚ activity.

The interface for configuring the email settings (as seen in ) requires two properties for normal mail traffic. The first property, Hostname, is the name of your SMTP mail server (e.g. mail.mycompany.com or 4.79.181.14). The second property is port. The standard port for sending email via SMTP is 25. You should only change this setting if you know your mail server is using a non-standard port.
For sites using authenticated SMTP (SMTP which requires a username and password), the Authentication Login and Authentication Password fields should be set. Otherwise, these can be safely left blank.
The final property, From Address, provides a FROM value for emails sent from ⪚.

sect2.title: From-Safe List
sect2.para: The From-Safe List Tab, as seen in , lets Administrators review the safelist maintained by each user.
Users populate their safelist based on mails which were incorrectly quarantined (see ). As seen in , administrators may browse and modify the safelists of individual users.
Note that if a user has not elected to place any addresses into their safelist, their account will not appear in this screen.

sect3.title: Quarantinable Forwards
sect3.para: The Quarantinable Forwards Tab, as seen in , provides a mechanism to quarantine emails destined for one address to another.

The Quarantinable Forwards feature was added to accomidate distribution lists which receive spam. Consider the list sales@yourcompany.com. There may be a team of 5 sales professionals who read the emails on this list. When a spam is sent to sales@yourcompany.com, all 5 members of the list would receive quarantine digests.

Having 5 people maintain the same quarantine inbox may become confusing. To avoid this confusion, Administrators can cause emails being quarantined for one address to be routed to another. For example, if the sales@yourcompany.com list goes to Emma, Joey, Jun, Aaron, and Cho, the administrator can declare that unwanted email going to sales@yourcompany.com be placed in the inbox emma@yourcompany.com.

To add a new forward to the list, push the add (plus) button to the right. A new row is added to the screen. The meaning of each entry is as follows:
distribution list address
The address receiving unwanted email to be re-routed to another inbox. Although technically this does not have to be a distribution list, this is the normal usage. In the previous example, this would be sales@yourcompany.com.
send to address
The email address corresponding to the inbox to sequester the email. In the previous example, this would be emma@yourcompany.com.

Although perhaps a subtle point, the release behavior with Quarantine Forwards does not continue the forwarding. With our previous example, if an email quarantined for sales@yourcompany.com is released by Emma, it will be received by Emma as well as Joey, Jun, Aaron, and Cho.

sect3.title: General Settings
sect3.para: The General Settings tab, as seen in , provides administrative access to overall Quarantine properties.

There are three settings on the General Settings Tab. Their meaning is as follows.
Maximum Holding Time
This is the maximum time (in days) that a given email can be maintained within an inbox. If the mail is not purged/released within this time, the mail will be automatically deleted by ⪚.
Digest From Address
This is the From as it appears on digest emails sent to end users.
Digest Sending Time
This is the time of day when the daily digest emails are sent.
